body: use gcc5.4 ,worked.

I can compile it with VC2015 as a stand alone C++ project. But I created a Common Language Runtime (CLR) DLL with /clr complier flag. That found a bug in implicit type casting of nullptr in statement 
`blob_ptr_ = std::make_shared<MXDataIterBlob>(nullptr)`. It needed a static cast, and with that the bug was resolved. 
`blob_ptr_ = std::make_shared<MXDataIterBlob>(static_cast<DataIterHandle>(nullptr))`
print out metric.sum_metric and metric.num_inst to see if they are integers

Thanks for help! The issue occurs because metric.sum_metric is not equal to the number of validation samples if validation batch size cannot divide the number of samples.

Hey @CarlosUziel 

Thank you for the reply.

I will try out your approach.

I have a rather biased binary class situation where 0 class to 1 class ratio is about 19:1. But I suppose it's similar for all one vs all situation.

When I just use default accuracy metric the result is around 95% which seems not right to me because it's too close to the 19:1 ratio.

I tried to use F1 score but it's constantly stuck at 0.000000 no matter the number of epoch or output layer being SoftmaxOutput or LogisticRegressionOutput. So I am no sure where I got it wrong.

In python, it is common to alias the mxnet package as "mx". I don't use R, but I don't see you doing so in your code; try using "mxnet" instead of "mx". If that isn't the problem, you should probably create a separate issue, since this issue was on an unrelated matter and is already closed.

mx.symbol.SliceChannel(data = data, num_outputs=2, axis = 0)
parameter axis can control which axis
if target shape is (32,1,20), mx.symbol.SliceChannel(data = data, num_outputs=50, axis = 1)

@starimpact 

The error is due to the update in `DiagrammeR`. It breaks many packages including `mxnet` and `xgboost`.

I have updated the related code. However, I don't have access to any Windows machine now, so the Windows pkg hasn't been updated. Please try to install the old version of `DiagrammeR`.

```r
require(devtools)
install_version("DiagrammeR", version = "0.8.1", repos = "http://cran.us.r-project.org")
```

I had the same issue in python 2.7.12 (Ubuntu 16.04). Changing order of importing can solve it.
```python 
import xgboost as xgb
import mxnet as mx
```
instead of:
```python
import mxnet as mx  
import xgboost as xgb
```

very long time to consume

After having a look at the test suite, I realized that maybe I am just misunderstanding the NDArrayIter API.

Could you pleas confirm that for the data parameter, we have a IndexedSeq[NDArray] where:

- the NDArray has a Shape of Shape(Number-of-images-to-predic, image.width, image.height)
- If the IndexedSeq has multiple (NDArray) elements, it is because the network has multiple inputs

If the above is correct, then my example code is wrong and the issue can be closed (however, the error message is still very difficult to understand).
it is mainly at cudaStreamCreate and cudaMalloc, it will block there and consume a very long time, about several minutes, why? thank you
you can refer to this PR. it works although it does not pass CI https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/4667

My networks are able to train and converge now with a nonsquare stride with this patch otherwise I hit  [this error](https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow/blob/ccab3b9a41ac2e1dbe5376011db3044b39a033c3/mshadow/extension/pack_col2patch.h#L51) message due to the fact that it only considers one dim of the kernel

@yxzf if you compile the mxnet without cuda, try to modify the 

CLASS_PATH=$MXNET_ROOT/scala-package/assembly/linux-x86_64-gpu/target/* ...
to
CLASS_PATH=$MXNET_ROOT/scala-package/assembly/linux-x86_64-cpu/target/* ...

in the script
